Export Banner Crosstabs to Formatted Excel Workbook

write_banners.Rd

This function takes a list of banner crosstab tables and exports them to a formatted Excel workbook. Each table becomes a separate worksheet with appropriate styling, including borders and column dividers. A Table of Contents sheet with hyperlinks is automatically generated.

Usage

write_banners(banners, file, overwrite = TRUE)

Arguments

banners

A list of data frames, typically the output from banner analysis functions. Each element should have the following attributes:

  • target: Character string used as the worksheet name

  • col_dividers: Numeric vector indicating column positions for right borders

  • label: Optional character string for display labels (falls back to target name)

file

A character string specifying the output file path for the Excel workbook. Should include the .xlsx extension.

overwrite

A logical value indicating whether to overwrite an existing file. Default is TRUE.

Value

Invisibly returns NULL. The function is called for its side effect of creating and writing an Excel file.

Details

The function creates a formatted Excel workbook with the following features:

  • worksheets: Each element in the input list becomes a separate sheet

  • formatting: Applies medium borders to column dividers and headers

  • Table of Contents: A dedicated first sheet with hyperlinks to all other sheets

  • Styled borders: Right borders at column divider positions and bottom borders on headers

  • Automatic naming: Uses the target attribute for sheet names

The Table of Contents sheet is automatically positioned as the first sheet and includes:

  • A formatted header with larger, bold text

  • Hyperlinked entries for each worksheet (note: hyperlink functionality may have limitations)

  • Wider column width for better readability

  • Blue tab color for visual distinction

Column dividers are applied based on the col_dividers attribute, which should contain the column numbers where right borders should be applied to visually separate different banner sections.

Note

The hyperlink functionality in the Table of Contents may have limitations depending on Excel version and settings (as noted in the function comments).

Each data frame in the input list must have the required attributes (target and col_dividers) for proper formatting. Missing attributes may result in errors or suboptimal formatting.

See also

banners for creating banner analysis results, createWorkbook for Excel workbook creation, addWorksheet for adding worksheets, saveWorkbook for saving Excel files

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Assuming you have banner analysis results
banner_results <- banners(
  design = my_design,
  target = "satisfaction",
  banners = list("age_group", "gender", "region")
)

# Export to Excel with default settings
write_banners(
  banners = list(satisfaction = banner_results),
  file = "survey_banners.xlsx"
)

# Export multiple banner analyses
multiple_results <- list(
  satisfaction = banner_results,
  awareness = other_banner_results
)

write_banners(
  banners = multiple_results,
  file = "all_survey_results.xlsx",
  overwrite = FALSE
)
} # }
